ratings.comment: Great class on algebraic topology. Professor Sam goes fast, but I learned a lot as a result. He also typesetted his own notes, which were very clear and great.
Sam is a wonderful professor, and I had wonderful TA for this class (it was Fall 2023)

Well, he is definitely a talented person, but sometimes he explains things too fast so his students may not understand things well before jumping into the next topic. But he gives rather easy homework and exams, and shout out to his TA Suhas, very helpful teaching assistance, explain things well and guide me through homework.
Avoid him at all cost
Avoid taking undergrad classes with him if you can, he goes through topics too fast without explaining the algorithms behind the topic.

worst math professor ever! his lectures are hard to understand, as i asked many of my classmates, they all could hardly understand his lecture. It seemed he is teaching to himself in the class, and i learnt all it by myself. His homework and exam are extremely difficult, often average to fail though he cut the total degree from 120 to 80.

NEVER EVER TRY TO TAKE HIS CLASSES. The most regretful thing I did. Before taking his class,  I has gpa 4.0, so I don’t think I am that stupid. But this course is really really difficult. The average final score is around 50%, which is a fail, though he finally gave us some curve. Anyway, be sure not even try to take his classes!!!

This man once proved that a bucket with a hole in it will fill up with water. Does anything else need to be said? I would characterize Professor Sam as someone who is a very smart mathematician, but utterly fails to communicate even the simplest concepts in this course across to his students.

I came into college a math lover, and thanks to this course and this professor, I will never be taking a math class again.  The concepts are difficult, and all he does in class is do practice problems on the board.  All of these problems are straight from the book (where the work is also shown so you would think he should do different problems).

I wasn't very fond of Prof. Sam. He mumbled, spoke at the board, and was really difficult to understand conceptually. This was by far the hardest course I've taken, and lectures never clarified my understanding; I learned everything from my TA. Also, exams are worth 90% of your grade, so if you bomb one, you're basically screwed.

Steven Sam was a terrible professor. His lectures were long, confusing, and very boring. He rushed through all the content, leaving us all lost. I learned way more from my TA, who didn't even speak English well. I would avoid having him for Math 222 at all costs, since the course is already extremely difficult.

Professor Sams lectures consist of him quickly covering material and examples directly from the book. His rapid pace results in precious time spent backtracking and answering questions, which he does poorly. That being said, if you have a strong math background and most of the material covered is review for you, the class is manageable.

He goes extremely fast through material during lecture, doesn't explain himself well, and is very test heavy (final was 45% of the grade). His midterms are tough and the average on the final was 47%. Not impossible to get an A because he curves grades at the end of the semester, but a really hard class overall.
Avoid if you can. It'll make your life much easier. Long story short, I'm sure he's a good guy, but not a good professor.

He makes many mistakes, works at a rapid pace, copies from the textbook, and is reluctant to answer questions. The average score on the final was a 47%, and I think this reflects the quality of his teaching. A good grade is achievable with the curve. I put in a lot of effort and earned an A, but I don't think I actually learned anything.

I think salty students who didn't want to put the time in projected their anger onto Professor Sam. He does have his shortcomings, like doing examples directly out of the book and talking into the board, but I thought he did a good job teaching a difficult course. His exams are very difficult, and the final was weighted at 45% of the overall grade.

The lectures are awful and he always made simple mistakes. Reading textbooks and attending discussions are the best ways to take this course. If you understand all concepts and are able to solve all problems on the worksheet and review packets, you will easily get an A. Don't choose him if you can, unless you prefer self-study.

Exams are worth 90% of your grade. 45% is how much the final is weighted. This professor is crazy and has no idea what he is doing. Both midterms were easy, but the final was disgustingly hard. (47% average) Class will be curved, but still, he has way too much emphasis on tests. He allows Notecards but they will barely help. Get ready to be creamed
He is a smart teacher, but he teaches poorly, and the exams are really really hard.

Horrible professor. He goes at a rapid pace, makes mistakes, and claims the mistakes don't matter. Lectures become pointless and since the Math 222 textbook is written awfully, find a tutor or use khan academy/youtube to teach yourself. The first two midterms weren't that bad, but the final for this class is worth 45% of the grade.

This professor teaches really fast and sometimes makes mistakes. I usually skip the class and use my friend's notes. It's truly hard but not that hard because if you understand all the notes and participate all the discussion sessions (which is important), you can also get a good grade.

My final was worth 45% of my final grade. Lectures were incredibly confusing due to lack of concrete examples. Exams were not too bad for the most part. If you have a bad TA you better find a tutor. Overall pretty rough experience.

He rambles, doesn't seem to know what he's doing and simply copies things from the terrible textbook. Worse course I've taken its all about beating the curve which means half the class is destined to do poorly.

Steven Sam came to lecture every day with absolutely no idea what he was going to talk about, and it showed.  He simply worked his way through the textbook with no idea where he was going with anything.  I sincerely believe I could have attended zero lectures and been just as successful, as my TA was very helpful in teaching us everything.

His lectures are awful. He just reads straight from the book and skips steps assuming you just know what hes doing. He gives no help I have relied only on my TA for help and he is just awful. We ended up a chapter further than we needed to be for no reason and I couldn't explain the last chapter. He's awful. Avoid.

When students ask questions, he makes them feel stupid by saying "that's very simple" or "you should know that" rather than answering the question. Most times, he never finishes his examples during lecture and/or confuses himself. He is very unenthusiastic about what he teaches and does a lot of proofs rather than giving examples.

Not good.  He races through examples and often makes mistakes that are discovered at the end.  He then continues on as if we understand what he just did.  When people ask questions he pretty much just looks at them in disbelief and comes off as condescending.

He exactly copied what the textbook says on his lecture without any explanation. He also expected you to do hard questions on the exams. He just told you how to compute "one plus one", and let you do integrals on the exams.

He literally copied the book onto the board. He had a tendency to talk at the board as he read out of the book and mumbled quite frequently. He also worked incredibly fast and skipped steps but then got frustrated when students asked too many clarifying questions. Other professors could explain things much more clearly and in than half the time

He's tough because he goes at a very fast pace, but he's always willing to stop and clarify if you ask. I pretty much hated him the first few weeks, but by the end of the semester he was probably my favorite prof. Lectures are fast paced, but homework is really helpful and office hours are great. Overall, tough class but a cool guy.
